awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Early understanding of personal and social causes of intentional action:  A cross-cultural investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
In the first few years of life, infants and children rapidly learn about the social world by observing and interacting with the people in their immediate environment.  These people are the first source of information as children begin to learn about human behavior and social norms shaping that behavior. The goal of this study is to examine how contextual factors influence the manner in which children interpret the behavioral intentions of others.  With a focus on social-cognitive development, this study addresses how children learn about the goals and desires of others and how children learn about the rules and norms of various social groups. In this global age, individuals are increasingly required to understand multiple worldviews. This study will foster skills needed to promote positive social behaviors and sensitivity to the norms and values of different cultural groups in the United States, which, in turn, will reduce harmful stereotyping and misunderstandings.

Understanding the perspectives, norms, and conventions of various individuals will help children develop a better understanding of their own place in the social world. This study investigates the mechanisms underlying the process by which children acquire this understanding.  The study also examines cultural differences and similarities in how children interpret intentional actions over the first five years of life. This will be accomplished by tracking emerging developmental changes in understandings of personal and social causes of intentional action at three time points starting in infancy and continuing on to the preschool years. Two cultural groups will be compared: European- and Chinese-Americans. The study also involves examining how infants, toddlers, and preschoolers employ statistical learning mechanisms in interpreting behavior.  The methodological approach consists of a critical third party generalization task; this means that having learned about the behaviors (and intentions) of one person, investigators will determine whether infants and children are able to predict the behaviors (and intentions) of an unfamiliar person.  A statistical learning measure will be used to determine how infants and children across cultures use statistical information to infer goals and desires of individuals. For example, if a young child grows up in a culture in which actions are governed by common cultural norms and practices as opposed to personal preferences, and thus observes consistency across individuals, that child may learn, over time, that observed intentional actions are frequently generalizable across individuals. In contrast, if a young child grows up in a culture in which actions are frequently expressions of idiosyncratic personal tastes, and thus, observes variability across individuals, then, that child may learn over time that intentional actions are not necessarily generalizable across individuals. Three age groups will be assessed: infants (ages 11-13 months), toddlers (ages 28-32 months) and preschoolers (ages 3-5 years).  Central questions posed include: Are children's predictions regarding the intentions of others a function of the sociocultural group to which the children belong? At what age do socioculturally-based inferences begin to surface?

por.por_cntn:
To be fully functional social beings, children must understand humans in two ways: as individuals, and as members of social groups. The understanding of individuals helps us consider diverse perspectives in order to learn about and relate to those who are important to us. The understanding of social groups causes help us consider our place in the social world, and learn about the norms, rules, and conventions that enable us to become active participants in our culture. The questions of how children learn about individual people and how they learn about the rules and norms of social groups have until now been investigated as separate areas of study in social-cognitive development. Here we have attempted to systematically combine them both under a common theoretical framework (Rational Constructivism, e.g. Xu & Kushnir, 2013) and using a common methodology. 

In a series of laboratory studies, we explored how 4-year-old children use statistical evidence and domain-specific knowledge to learn whether actions are personal (idiosyncratic to a particular individual) or social (shared across individuals). The method across studies centers around a third-party generalization task: having learned about the behaviors (and intentions) of one person, we see whether children predict the behavior (and intentions) of unfamiliar person. Generalization indicates that children have learned, from one set of actions of one individual, about behaviors common to members of a social or cultural group. Our methods also contain a statistical learning measure to see how children across cultures incorporate statistical information into their inferences.

The sample was chosen to represent a cultural contrast that may result in diverging patterns with development: Children in the US and children in Shanghai, China. Our hypotheses are based on well-documented differences between East Asian and Western parenting practices, as well as well studied differences in adult social cognition.  If cultural input is responsible for shaping these worldviews, these biases should be revealed increasingly with age in young children’s predictions about human behavior.

Study 1 (in person, N = 159, Mean Age = 4.08 years, SD = 0.76 years) investigated how preschool children across two cultural groups use statistical patterns of actions and domain to infer what types of actions are personal versus socially shared via the third-party generalization measure mentioned above. Despite the early termination of the study because of the COVID-19 pandemic, we were able to obtain results indicating that generalizations were domain-dependent, but culturally similar. Each domain showed a distinct pattern of generalization: Four-year-old children did not generalize preferences from one individual to another, suggesting that they thought that preferences were idiosyncratic to an individual. In contrast, children overwhelmingly generalized new words across individuals. Finally, children were more likely to generalize object functions across individuals, but these results depended on the statistical evidence, and was more variable across cultural groups.

When Study 1 was cut short, interesting results were emerging regarding non-linguistic conventions. Because of this we conducted a second study (Study 2 online via Zoom, N = 234, Mean Age = 4.05 years, SD = 0.79 years) as a registered replication and extension of Study 1. Using video presentations of stimuli, we contrasted children's inferences about preferences with two types of non-linguistic conventions: object functions and game rules. Importantly, we controlled the visual displays by using the same video stimuli for object functions and game rules, and varying only the way the actions were framed. The results of Study 2 replicated the contrast between preferences and non-linguistic conventions found in Study 1: Children in the US and China did not generalize actions framed as preferences from one individual to another, and they were more likely to generalize actions framed as "rules" or "functions" from one individual to another. Importantly, even though actions were identical, framing them as "rules of a game" let to more variable rates of generalization than framing them as "functions of an object."  We also found a cultural main effect: children in China were more likely to generalize in the non-linguistic convention conditions than children in the US.

In sum, across studies we use third-party generalization measure in combination with statistical evidence to systematically explore domain and cultural effects on children's inferences about actions of individuals and social groups. Our results show domain effects on children's cultural learning as early as 4 years of age; despite seeing very similar patterns of actions across domains, children infer that some actions are more likely to be indicative of socially-shared knowledge than others. In our work, cultural similarities between the two groups sampled outweighed than cultural differences, as children in the US and China tended to use the social and statistical information similarly in their learning.

Our original proposal included infants and toddlers, but due to the pandemic data collection with these ages is still on hold. We hope to resume this work as soon as possible.
